node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: In recent years, “Karen” has become an epithet for a type of interfering, hectoring white woman, the self-appointed hall monitor unloosed on the world, so assured of her status in society that she doesn’t hesitate to summon the authorities — demanding to speak to the manager or calling the police — for the most trivial and often wholly imaginary transgressions. This manifests alarmingly in confrontations with people of color, and particularly Black people. The name is a relic of an older, more conservative America, catapulted from relative obscurity to the 20 most popular choices for newborn girls in 1941 and hovering near the top of the list for three decades. Ubiquity rendered Karen generic, an emblem of conformity, granting her the safety of being thoroughly average. By 2020, its usage, already in severe decline before its hijacking as a term of mockery, had fallen to pre-Depression levels. But long before the name Karen infiltrated American culture, it was a Danish contraction of Katherine, which is attributed variously (onomasts are uncertain) to the Greek “katharos” — “pure, clean, unsullied” — or to Hecate, the Greek goddess of witchcraft, who, surrounded by watchdogs, presides over places of transition: crossroads, borders, graveyards. What is left of these roots in the modern Karen? Certainly, she sets herself up as a guardian of purity, patrolling boundaries at a time when a white-dominated society is transforming into a multicultural one and condemning disruptions of what she sees as the proper order. But what does this narrative say — and elide — about racism and sexism today? Click the link in our bio to read @LigayaMishan’s full story, written for T’s Women’s issue. Pictured here is one of six collages, all titled “White Women Look Away” (2021), created by the artist Carmen Winant (@carmen.winant) exclusively for T.

node.text: All of the above is cake. The West has long delighted in the treachery of food in disguise. One recent example? Last summer, BuzzFeed’s Tasty shared a video on Twitter that opened on a close-up of a knife looming over a red Croc sandal. There was barely a moment for the viewer to register the banality of the shoe before the knife, wielded by a black-gloved hand, cut it brusquely in half, revealing layers of yellow and pink cake. More ordinary objects followed — all cake and all the work of the pastry chef Tuba Geckil, whose creations struck a chord, even if no one was really fooled. The riddle of the trompe l’oeil cake is simple. It’s solved in an instant, with the stroke of the knife. And the materials matter: The cake is cake, whatever its makeover, with a primal promise of comfort. Maybe the lure isn’t the cleverness of the deception at all, but the cake as endgame — the reward that makes all the absurdity (of a cake that looks like a bottle of hand sanitizer, of life in general), worthwhile. Click the link in our bio for @LigayaMishan’s full story, written for T’s Women’s issue. Visuals by Kyoko Hamada (@kyokopajama), food styling by Miko Kaw Hok Uy (@mikokawhokuy), prop styling by Victoria Petro-Conroy (@victoriapconroy). #TWomensIssue

node.text: Thao Nguyen (@thaogetstaydown), the frontwoman of the Bay Area band Thao & the Get Down Stay Down, grew up in Virginia, where her parents found refuge after the fall of Saigon. “Temple,” released last spring, is her fifth album, and the first to bring her family background to the fore. “I had never addressed it in my work because I had never addressed it in my life,” she says. The Brooklyn-based singer Michelle Zauner (@jbrekkie), of the band Japanese Breakfast (whose new album, “Jubilee,” came out in June), had hesitations, too, when she was starting out. “I masked certain parts of myself to command a level of seriousness,” she says. Only when she had given up hope of commercial success, in the wake of her mother’s death from cancer in 2014, did she make her biography public, putting a photograph of her mother on the cover of her album “Psychopomp” (2016). On the record’s brief, hushed title track we hear her mother, from an old voice mail, speaking half in Korean, half in English. “Gwenchana, gwenchana,” she says, which translates to “it’s OK.” Click the link in our bio for @LigayaMishan’s full story, written for T’s Fall Women’s issue, on the Asian pop stars taking center stage. Photos by Collier Schorr (@collierschorrstudio), styled by Matt Holmes (@matttholmesss). #TWomensIssue

node.text: For decades, there was little room in mainstream Western pop for women who were visually discernible as Asian. Yet today in the West, women and girls of Asian descent are splicing rat-a-tat rhymes with ethereal R&B, sneering through dank electronic reveries, mauling guitars and smirking at mics, streaming brokenhearted lullabies from their childhood bedrooms to audiences of millions, making indie folk, bubble gum pop, club bangers, punk howlers and all the music outside and in between: Audrey Mika, Audrey Nuna, Beabadoobee, Caro Juna, Charli XCX, Chloe Tang, Daya, Deb Never, Dolly Ave, Emily Vu, Griff, Hayley Kiyoko, H.E.R., Jaguar Jonze, Jay Som, Jhené Aiko, Joyce Wrice, Krewella, Laufey, the Linda Lindas, Luna Li, Madame Gandhi, Milck, Mitski, mxmtoon, Nayana IZ, Niki, Priya Ragu, Raveena, Rei Ami, Rina Sawayama, Sanjana, Saweetie, Umi, Yaeji, as well as Ruby Ibarra, Thao Nguyen, Bella Poarch, Olivia Rodrigo, Michelle Zauner and more, an ever-lengthening incantation. What do these women share? As @LigayaMishan writes in her recent essay for T’s Fall 2021 Women’s issue, Asian musicians in the West have had to navigate between self-Orientalizing and self-erasure. Today’s artists resist these oppositions, and, in the process, are transforming their respective genres. Click the link in our bio for Mishan’s full story. Pictured: Thao Nguyen (@thaogetstaydown), @RubyIbarra, @AudreyNuna and Michelle Zauner (@jbrekkie) photographed by Collier Schorr (@collierschorrstudio), styled by Matt Holmes (@matttholmesss). #TWomensIssue

node.text: The Tokyo Games may have come to a close this past Sunday, but some legacies stretch across multiple Olympics. In 1968, the American sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos raised their fists during a medal ceremony in Mexico City — a symbolic act that, as Smith has said, was about human rights through the particulars of Black people’s struggle. “I needed to make a symbol of strength and power. I needed something to make whole. Not stand up and just do nothing. I needed a movement,” he told Adam Bradley for a recent essay for T. Smith and Carlos’s protest did not invent the raised fist, but it may well have apotheosized it, distilling it to a forceful and seductive expression of intention. Decades later, their demonstration still inspires athletes, artists and marginalized people everywhere. As the artist Hank Willis Thomas said, “I think that Tommie Smith is immortal because of that gesture.” Click the link in our bio for Bradley’s full story. Pictured: Smith (center) and Carlos (right) during the medal ceremony. Silver medalist Peter Norman of Australia (left), who wore an OPHR button in solidarity with Smith and Carlos and voiced his support to them in words, stands by. Image courtesy of John Dominis/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Shutterstock.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Architect Christopher Rawlins’s (@rawlinsdesign) favorite room of his Inwood apartment may be the kitchen, where the extra-deep sink can keep up to 10 place settings’ worth of dirty dishes out of view when he’s entertaining. He also installed a wet zone, which features a continuous plane of white Corian that goes from the ceiling, over the zebrawood veneer countertop, and down to the floor — “It’s a waterfall effect on steroids,” says Rawlins — and, because Corian can melt, a hot zone, with an island topped with green granite that looks more like marble. Click the link in our bio for more. Photo by Blaine Davis (@blaineduh).

node.text:
Dear Culture Therapist, 
Is it true that if a woman hasn’t achieved her highest good by age 55 she never will? Do you have any books or films you’d recommend about women yearning for more creatively? I have loved celebrating the work of others and wonder what my best work is or if it has been done yet.

“In the middle of adulthood it’s easy to envy those merely on the brink of it, with their imagined freedom to wander and aspire and their seemingly endless (and endlessly squandered) free time — forgetting how much of those rootless years were eaten up by uncertainty and fear,” writes #TCultureTherapist @LigayaMishan. “But surely the word ‘best’ is no more useful for comparing early and late work than for defining the different times of your life.” And, she adds, “There is a quiet ferocity to continuing, a force captured in the Brooklyn-based artist @MickaleneThomas’s 2012 short film, ‘Happy Birthday to a Beautiful Woman,’ which offers a portrait of her mother, Sandra Bush, a statuesque former model and, before she fell ill with kidney disease, the glamorous subject of a number of Thomas’s paintings. Here Thomas interrogates her own framing of her mother’s beauty, as Bush speaks to the tumult of her past, answering intimate questions about her difficult marriage to Thomas’s father and her drug addiction, while maintaining an armor of elegance — rich dark lipstick, light glancing off her jewelry — and regal to the end.”

Click the link in our bio for the full response. Pictured: A clip from Mickalene Thomas's video "Happy Birthday to a Beautiful Woman" (2012). © Mickalene Thomas

node.text: When the @Guggenheim’s assistant curator X Zhu-Nowell invited the artist Wu Tsang (@wu_tsang) to exhibit one of her films last summer, Tsang proposed an ambitious new site-specific work. The resulting video and sound installation, “Wu Tsang: Anthem,” marks the first of its scope in the museum’s rotunda. It presents a film-portrait of the composer, singer and transgender activist @BeverlyGlennCopeland, who produced striking and soulful experimental albums in relative obscurity beginning in the ’70s, until a recent surge in interest from cult record collectors led to the 2016 reissue of his 1986 studio album “Keyboard Fantasies” and an international tour in 2017, as well as a 2019 feature documentary by Posy Dixon. Like many of Tsang’s works — which combine narrative, documentary and fantasy to explore states of “in-betweenness” — “Anthem” is a collaboration with its subject: “I’m always trying to find ways to distill the essence of what that performer’s energy is,” says Tsang. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Chantal McStay. Photo by David Heald © Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 2021. #TList

node.text: #T25Buildings: In the middle of the 20th century, when many of the world’s prominent architects strove to eradicate ornament, Carlo Scarpa built a career on his eye for precision, material and, above all, place. He brought all of those talents to bear in his renovation of the ground floor and entrance of the Fondazione Querini Stampalia, established in 1869 as a museum and library set in a centuries-old palazzo in the heart of Venice, his hometown. Meticulous in its attention to detail — see the delicate mosaic tiling on the entry hall floor and elaborately worked channels and drains that weave through the garden’s labyrinthine fountains — the project, which began in 1949, was also prescient in its adaptability to the vicissitudes of nature. Restoring the deteriorated ground floor and gardens, Scarpa raised a walkway over an open space where water from the canal outside flows in through sea gates, splashing constantly against the Istrian stone steps, a reminder of the mercurial lagoon that shapes every aspect of the city’s life. Click the link in our bio for T’s full list of the 25 most influential buildings erected or updated since World War II.
